title: MEX rose
statementHtml:
You are given an array aa of length nn and a number kk, where 0≤k≤n0≤k≤n.

In one operation, you can choose any index ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n) and set aiai to any integer value xx from the range [0,n][0,n].

Find the minimum number of such operations required to satisfy the condition: MEX(a)MEX(a)∗∗=k=k

∗∗The minimum excluded (MEX) of a set of numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an is the smallest non-negative integer xx that does not appear among the aiai.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test consists of several sets of input data.

The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of sets of input data. The description of the sets of input data follows.

The first line of each set of input data contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅105,0≤k≤n1≤n≤2⋅105,0≤k≤n) — the length of the array aa and the required MEX(a)MEX(a).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n) — the elements of the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of the values of nn across all sets of input data does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each set of input data, output one integer — the minimum number of operations required to satisfy the condition MEX(a)=kMEX(a)=k.
noteHtml:
In the first set of input data, the array a=[0]a=[0], so MEX=1MEX=1. By removing zero (replacing it with any x∈[1,n]x∈[1,n]), we get MEX=0MEX=0. Thus, exactly one operation is required.

In the third set of input data, the array contains all the numbers 0,1,2,3,40,1,2,3,4, so MEX(a)=5MEX(a)=5 from the start.

Since this matches the required kk, no changes are needed and the minimum number of operations is 00.
